question_stem: The discriminant of a quadratic equation \(3x^2 + px + 2 = 0\) is greater than zero.

parts.question_text: Find the set of possible values of \(p\).
parts.solution_text:
The discriminant of the quadratic equation \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\) is given by \(b^2 - 4ac\). In this case, \(a=3\), \(b=p\), and \(c=2\). We are given that the discriminant is greater than zero, so
\(p^2 - 4(3)(2) > 0\)
\(p^2 - 24 > 0\)
\(p^2 > 24\)
Taking the square root of both sides, we get
\(|p| > \sqrt{24}\)
\(|p| > 2\sqrt{6}\)
This means that either \(p > 2\sqrt{6}\) or \(p < -2\sqrt{6}\). 
Therefore, the set of possible values for \(p\) is \(p < -2\sqrt{6}\) or \(p > 2\sqrt{6}\).
